#â€‹693 â€” June 20, 2024

Read on the Web

JavaScript Weekly

The Results of the State of JavaScript 2023 Survey â€” It feels odd including something about 2023 in June 2024, but the results of the major annual JavaScript developer survey are now out. Itâ€™s interesting to see what features JS devs do and donâ€™t use, changes in library popularity over time, what build tools people are using, the divide between JavaScript and TypeScript usage, and much more besides.

Devographics

How JavaScript is Finally Improving the Module Experience â€” Multiple long-term proposals collectively known as â€œmodule harmonyâ€ will complete the features lost as developers move away from CommonJS.

Mary Branscombe / The New Stack

Simplify Your Data Collection with a Fully Integrated Form Management Platform â€” SurveyJS is an open-source JavaScript library suite for secure form creation and data collection in your app. Build JSON-driven surveys/forms quickly, without manual coding. Integrate with any backend system, gather and store responses while retaining full control over your data.

SurveyJS sponsor

How React 19 (Almost) Made the Internet Slower â€” Even changes that are planned in advance can have big effects on the developer experience if people arenâ€™t aware of them. A change to Suspense in React 19 led to much confusion and surprise, but the story has a happy ending with the React team ready to listen to end users more closely.

Henrique Yuji

IN BRIEF:

  • Evan You, the creator of Vue.js, recently gave â–¶ï¸ a talk on 10 years of Vue, covering both its past and future.

  • Over on Twitter/X, Daniel Lemire showed off a situation where Bun is much faster than Node.js, even when both are using the same underlying library, due to the complexities the V8 engine introduces.

  • ğŸµ Did you know TC39 now has its own pop group and a song?

RELEASES:

  • htmx 2.0 â€“ The popular 'access lots of JS and Web API features via special HTML attributes' library gets a new major version mainly to remove deprecations and drop IE support.

  • Electron 31 â€“ The cross-platform desktop app framework steps up to Chromium 126, Node 20.14, and V8 12.6.

  • Relay 17 â€“ Facebook's declaritive GraphQL client for React.

  • ESLint 9.5, Serverless Framework v4, pnpm 9.4

Your Fastest Path to Production â€” Build, deploy, and scale your apps with unparalleled ease â€“ from your first user to your billionth.

Render sponsor

ğŸ“’ Articles & Tutorials

â–¶  3D in TypeScript with Raycasting â€” Raycasting is a somewhat old fashioned technique to render 3D environments (you may have seen it in 1992â€™s Wolfenstein 3D) but itâ€™s easy to understand and worth implementing at least once.

Tsoding Daily

Live Types in a TypeScript Monorepo â€” Several strategies to make a TypeScript monorepo feel more â€œaliveâ€ in the sense of the propagation of changes.

Colin McDonnell

Intro to Sentry & Codecov: Live Demo â€” From pre to post-release, learn how Sentry help developers find and fix errors and slowdowns and deploy with confidence.

Sentry sponsor

What Happens When a Major npm Library Goes Commercial? â€” The ua-parser-js library is commonly used to parse user agent strings and gets over 12 million downloads a month, but it has recently switched to AGPL+commercial licensing.

Matteo Collina

Dual Publishing ESM and CJS Modules with tsup and 'Are the Types Wrong' â€” tsup makes it easy to bundle TypeScript libraries and 'Are the Types Wrong?' analyzes packages for issues with their types.

John Reilly

ğŸ“„ How to Use Google Sheets as a 'Database' from React Paul Scanlon

ğŸ“º How Svelte and RSCs are Changing Web Development â€“ A group discussion including Svelteâ€™s Rich Harris, Tracy Lee, Ben Lesh, and Adam Rackis. This Dot Media

ğŸ“„ Mastering Date Formatting using Intl.DateTimeFormat Rafael Camargo

ğŸ“„ MobX Memoizes Components (You Don't Need React Compiler) â€“ If youâ€™re actually using MobX, that is. Mike Johnson

ğŸ“„ Refactoring a Scroll-Driven Animation from JavaScript to CSS Andrico Karoulla

ğŸ“„ UUIDv7 Implemented in 20 Languages â€“ Surprisingly short and sweet. Anton Zhiyanov

ğŸ›  Code & Tools

Phoenix: A macOS Window Manager You Can Script with JS â€” macOS is set to adding more window management features in Sequoia, but how about something you can script entirely with JavaScript right now? GitHub repo.

Kasper Hirvikoski

JSONEditor: A Component for Viewing and Editing JSON â€” If your app needs to let users work with JSON directly, this is worth a look. It supports both text and tree views and is cross browser compatible. Live demo.

Jos de Jong

Transformational Auth & Identity | Userfront â€” "Compared to our previous experiences in the security/auth space, Userfront is an order of magnitude simpler to use."

Userfront sponsor

Rooster v9.6: Microsoft's Framework-Independent Rich Text Editor â€” A rich-text editor control neatly nested inside a single div element (demo). Several years old, but still maintained.

Microsoft

NLUX: A Library for Rendering Conversational AI Experiences â€” If you want to spin up a ChatGPT-style conversational experience on top of your own services or third party AI backends, this provides the pieces needed to get an interface up quickly. GitHub repo.

Salmen Hichri

âš™ï¸ NodeSwift â€“ Bridges Node.js and Swift so you can write Swift code that talks to Node and vice versa. Kabir Oberai

âš™ï¸ Vuesion â€“ Boilerplate for Next/Vue app development. Werner-Most Ideen GmbH

âš™ï¸ Kitbag Router â€“ Type safe router for Vue.js. Craig Harshbarger

QUICK RELEASES:

  • Electron Store 10.0 â€“ Simple data persistence for Electron apps.

  • React Date Picker 7.1 â€“ Simple date picker component. (Demo.)

  • Monads 0.7 â€“ Rust-inspired Option, Result, and Either types.

  • Plasmo 0.88 â€“ "Like Next.js for browser extensions."

  • MUI X 7.7 â€“ Popular React component suite.

  • React Tag Autocomplete 7.3

WorkOS: Enterprise-Grade Auth You Can Implement in Minutes â€” Like an enterprise plan in a box: WorkOS provides flexible, easy-to-use APIs to integrate SSO, SCIM, Audit Logs, User Management, and RBAC. It's used by some of the hottest startups including Perplexity, Vercel, & Webflow. Future-proof your auth stack with WorkOS.

How to Compose JS Functions That Take Multiple Parameters â€” â€œFunction composition is beautiful,â€ says James, who goes on to explain, in his usually elegant way, the use of partial application, currying, composite data structures, and more.

James Sinclair

'I Tried React Compiler Today, and Guess What..' â€” The recently unveiled React Compiler automatically memoizes things â€“ so can we ditch memo, useMemo and useCallback right away? Nadia investigates, finds the rough edges, and helps keep our feet on the ground.

Nadia Makarevich

'How a Single Vulnerability Can Bring Down the JS Ecosystem' â€” A slightly alarmist headline and itâ€™s more about npm, but the issue outlined could have nonetheless posed big problems â€“ luckily, GitHub is on the case.

Your Fastest Path to Production â€” Build, deploy, and scale your apps with unparalleled ease â€“ from your first user to your billionth.

#â€‹691 â€” June 6, 2024

Read on the Web

JavaScript Weekly

Promises from the Ground Up â€” Josh notes that in order to truly understand promises, a fundamental part of modern JS development, we need â€œa surprisingly deep understanding of how JavaScript works and what its limitations areâ€. Luckily, this tutorial covers all the critical context you need.

Josh W Comeau

ğŸ’¡ If you're a bit more advanced, you might enjoy Alex MacArthur's look at controlling promises using Promise.withResolvers().

A Powerful JavaScript Reporting Tool Built for the Web â€” ActiveReportsJS is the premier JavaScript reporting tool designed for advanced data visualizations in web applications. With many different advanced report builders and viewers, insights can be seamlessly shared with your entire user base.

ActiveReportsJS from MESCIUS inc sponsor

htmx: Simplicity in an Age of Complicated Solutions â€” htmx provides access to numerous dynamic features, like Ajax requests and page updates, by way of HTML attributes, and has been increasing in popularity recently. Erik looks at why its simplicity is particularly appealing.

Erik Heemskerk

ğŸ“º YouTuber DevelopedByEd has a neat â–¶ï¸ 15 minute Go + htmx quickstart screencast targeting JavaScript developers keen to explore new approaches.

IN BRIEF:

  • âš™ï¸ ESLint has unveiled a new ESLint configuration migrator to help bring your config files up to speed.

  • Astro's Starlight documentation site framework has turned one year old â€“ v1.0 is due later this year.

  • The Val Town bite-size JavaScript deployment platform is really taking off. They've added a page of trending Vals to show off what people are up to.

  • WebAssemblyâ€™s JavaScript Promise Integration (JSPI) API has a new API in Chrome 126+.

RELEASES:

  • Turborepo 2.0 â€“ The high-performance build system.

  • ESLint 9.4 â€“ Find and fix problems in your JavaScript code.

  • ğŸ¦– Docusaurus 3.4 â€“ The fantastic site / docs site framework.

  • Prettier 3.3, Biome 1.8, Ember.js 5.9, pnpm 9.2

Revolutionizing UI Development with Chromatic and StackBlitz â€” In our upcoming live stream, we'll be speaking with the Chromatic team about actionable strategies to improve your design system workflow.

StackBlitz sponsor

ğŸ“’ Articles & Tutorials

Data Fetching Patterns in Single-Page Applications â€” With a level of depth youâ€™d expect from a Martin Fowler production, Atlassianâ€™s Juntao Qiu walks through five different patterns to consider when fetching remote data, using a realistic scenario to show them off.

Juntao Qiu and Martin Fowler

A Brisk VS Code Extension Development Speedrun â€” Literally a brisk tutorial, but Brisk is also the name of a CI tool the extension in question is being developed for.

Sean Reilly

Tracing: Frontend Issues with Backend Solutions â€” Join us live to learn how to identify the issues causing poor Core Web Vitals and trace them through your stack.

Sentry sponsor

Full Stack Web Push API Guide â€” A complete implementation of push notifications in a Remix app. â€œIf you follow the walk through to the end, youâ€™ll have working push notifications.â€

Boaz Sender

ğŸ“„ Node Leaking Memory? setTimeout Could be the Reason Armin Ronacher

ğŸ“„ Write Your First Chrome Extension: A Guide Lizzie Paris

ğŸ“„ Goodbye Netlify, Hello Cloudflare â€“ When the bandwidth charges start to sting.. Harrison Broadbent

ğŸ“º Effortless Vue.js Forms CDRUC

ğŸ›  Code & Tools

Motion Canvas: Create Dynamic Canvas-Rendered Animations â€” Thereâ€™s two parts. A library where you use generator functions to procedurally define animations, and an editor that provides a real-time preview of said animations which you can see in action here.

Motion Canvas

Merge Anything 6.0: Merge Objects and Other Types Recursively â€” If youâ€™re looking for something that goes a bit deeper than Object.assign(), say.

Luca Ban

TypeScriptToLua: Write Lua with TypeScript â€” Lua is embedded in all sorts of places (games, Redis, NGINX..) so being able to write JavaScript and have it converted could open up some extra opportunities for you.

TypeScriptToLua Contributors

Breakpoints and console.log is the Past, Time Travel is the Future â€” 15x faster JavaScript debugging than with breakpoints and console.log, supports Vitest, jest, karma, jasmine, and more.

Wallaby Team sponsor

Zigar: Write and Use Zig Code in Node and Electron Projects â€” Zig is a newish systems language thatâ€™s essentially a superset of C/C++. Zigar wants to make using C/C++/Zig code easier in JavaScript projects.

Chung Leong

  • Wouter 3.2 â€“ Minimalist router for React & Preact. You can now use regular expressions to define custom route patterns too.

  • PKI.js 3.1 â€“ Pure JS library for working with public key oriented systems. Certificates, signing, etc.

  • Fontsource â€“ 1700+ open source fonts packaged as npm packages.

  • tscircuit â€“ Design circuit boards using a React-based approach.

  • Prisma 5.15 â€“ Popular ORM for Node.js and TypeScript.

  • melonJS 17.3 â€“ Lightweight HTML5 game engine.

ğŸ¤– A quick AI-side

First, a handy library:

KaTeX: The Fastest Math Typesetting Library for the Web â€” All these AI And machine learning papers and blog posts these days are crammed with mathematical notation, so how about a no dependency, TeX-based approach to rendering them? The sandbox demo page shows off how smooth it is.

Emily Eisenberg and Sophie Alpert

Second, you may recall that last year (in issue 654) I mentioned a new AI engineering event being put on by two JavaScript developers called The AI Engineer Summit. It turned out to be fantastic and it's back later this month in a much larger form called The AI Engineer World's Fair (June 25-27 in San Francisco).

The speaker list is a veritable 'who's who' of the ML-leaning development scene with all the main LLM providers present too, so I've decided, at the last minute, I need to be there! If you're interested in going too, they've given us a link with 30% off all the ticket prices for you to use.
